simulated_ratings.title: Mother! (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The claustrophobic, escalating allegory scratches my itch for psychological, high-concept chaos.

simulated_ratings.title: Tree of Life, The (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meditative, cosmic introspection paired with family memory gives me the kind of existential drift I enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: Fountain, The (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Romantic sci-fi spirituality across timelines feels bold and hypnotic even when it gets airy.

simulated_ratings.title: Martyrs (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal and metaphysical

simulated_ratings.title: Enemy (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A moral maze about vengeance and identity appeals, though the didactic edges blunt the impact.

simulated_ratings.title: Circle (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Minimalist high-concept with relentless moral debates is exactly my chamber-thriller sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Interstellar (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Big-hearted cosmic adventure with brainy ideas hits my sense of wonder despite some sentimentality.

simulated_ratings.title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A sensory, sinister character study that suits my taste for dark psychology.

simulated_ratings.title: Cloud Atlas (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ambitious time-hopping mosaic about cause and effect satisfies my love of sprawling, idea-driven sci-fi.

simulated_ratings.title: It's My Party (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intimate farewell drama that moves me even if it leans conventional.

simulated_ratings.title: Your Friends and Neighbors (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Acerbic, talky dissection of desire and cruelty that I appreciate more than I enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: Ghost in the Shell Arise - Border 4: Ghost Stands Alone (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek cyberpunk intrigue and tech-philosophy hook me even if I’m jumping in midstream.

simulated_ratings.title: Xiu Xiu: The Sent-Down Girl (Tian yu) (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, aching tragedy that works through restraint more than fireworks.

simulated_ratings.title: Beloved (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Haunting trauma-drenched drama with a supernatural edge that intrigues me despite some unevenness.

simulated_ratings.title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Macabre musical vengeance with gothic flair plays right into my dark-tinged tastes.

simulated_ratings.title: Pi (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoid math-mysticism and number obsession are my catnip.

simulated_ratings.title: Ravenous (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Genre-mashing cannibal western that’s fun and feral, if a bit uneven tonally.

simulated_ratings.title: What Happened Was... (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A small, awkward two-hander that quietly spirals into revealing, uncomfortable honesty.

simulated_ratings.title: Snow Falling on Cedars (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, slow-burn romance-mystery with atmosphere I can sink into.

simulated_ratings.title: Inception (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A precision-engineered dream heist with layered mind-games I could happily rewatch.

simulated_ratings.title: Shutter Island (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Psychological puzzle-box vibes and dread-laden atmosphere land well for me.

simulated_ratings.title: Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, The (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Epic, sincere fantasy payoff that I respect even if I’m more drawn to weirder worlds.

simulated_ratings.title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (Bir zamanlar Anadolu'da) (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hypnotic, existential nocturne where the investigation is really about the men looking inward.

simulated_ratings.title: Sunshine (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweeping generational tragedy that engages my head more than my heart.

simulated_ratings.title: Ponette (1996)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender, child’s-eye grief that feels honest and quietly devastating.

simulated_ratings.title: Governess, The (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody period romance with identity play that intrigues me without fully gripping me.

simulated_ratings.title: Solaris (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Melancholy, intimate sci-fi about memory and loss that matches my reflective wavelength.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K. 2017 (2017)

simulated_ratings.title: I'm Not There (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cubist identity play and musical mythmaking are exactly the kind of formal games I enjoy.

simulated_ratings.title: As Green As It Gets (2018)

simulated_ratings.title: Life as a House (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Earnest, manipulative but cathartic father-son melodrama that still gets under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: (500) Days of Summer (2009)

simulated_ratings.title: Garden State (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Words, The (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sober archival readings evoke the tragedy, but the format feels a bit museum-still to me.

simulated_ratings.title: Religulous (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smirking, globe-trotting skepticism that I appreciate in spurts despite the glib tone.

simulated_ratings.title: 127 Hours (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A disciplined, visceral chamber survival that locks me in and doesn’t let go.

simulated_ratings.title: Silver Linings Playbook (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: High-energy, messy-heart romance with mental-health edges that works more than it irks.

simulated_ratings.title: Apt Pupil (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dark psychological cat-and-mouse that crawls under the skin in exactly my register.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lego Movie (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meta-anarchic ingenuity and pop wit deliver idea-dense fun I can happily ride with.

simulated_ratings.title: Two Night Stand (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cute bottle-romcom premise, but the pat banter and beats feel factory-stamped.

simulated_ratings.title: First Time, The (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A terse, charged encounter that sketches desire and risk with bracing economy.

simulated_ratings.title: Red Ink (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A grim, socially aware puzzle that engages my curiosity even if it’s a bit schematic.

simulated_ratings.title: Louis C.K.: Chewed Up (2008)

simulated_ratings.title: Hanging Garden (2005)

simulated_ratings.title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fluid, tender friendships and identity blur in a melancholy register I respond to.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunger Games: Catching Fire (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick, oppressive spectacle with rebellion rumblings that I enjoy more as world-building than YA melodrama.

simulated_ratings.title: The Worthy (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, post-collapse siege mechanics and moral stressors land, even if the ambitions outpace the polish.
Glitter and longing at the door of the club, but the drama feels more surface than soul.

simulated_ratings.title: In My Father's Den (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody, memory-haunted mystery that sinks into me the way I like—quiet, probing, bruised.

simulated_ratings.title: 21 Grams (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Shattered-structure grief spiral and moral rot—grim, potent, squarely in my wheelhouse.

simulated_ratings.title: Cookie's Fortune (1999)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm-blooded small-town tangle with wry grace, if a shade too gentle for my darker tastes.
